How Voice Search is Changing Cannabis Marketing

Posted on June 3, 2025

Why Voice Search Matters for Cannabis Brands

Voice search isn’t some futuristic novelty—it’s already woven into the daily lives of consumers. Whether people ask Siri to check the weather or tell Alexa to reorder their favorite snacks, voice assistant usage is surging. One recent report from Nisonco notes that more than a quarter of Internet users perform voice searches at least once a week. Another study found that over 50 % of the global population uses voice search daily, and 62 % of American adults use a voice assistant on their smartphones. Those numbers will only rise as smart speakers become ubiquitous- Statista estimates three‑quarters of households will own a smart speaker by 2025.

This shift isn’t just a tech trend; it’s revolutionizing how people discover and interact with brands. For cannabis businesses, voice search represents both a huge opportunity and a new compliance challenge. Voice assistants deliver only one or two results, meaning visibility can drop to zero if you’re not optimized. And because cannabis remains heavily regulated, marketers must ensure that the content voice assistants read complies with advertising rules, no medical claims and nothing appealing to minors. In this post, we’ll explore how voice search is changing cannabis marketing and provide actionable tips to help your brand stand out.

Usage is exploding—especially among younger, tech‑savvy consumers

Voice search adoption isn’t limited to tech enthusiasts. Research from GWI shows that 32 % of consumers worldwide have used a voice assistant in the past week, with usage skyrocketing among millennials and Gen Z. These users aren’t just setting timers; 21 % use voice search to find information and 20 % use it to complete actions like ordering products. The same report notes that voice search usage grew by 46 % for Google Assistant between 2020 and 2024.

For cannabis businesses, whose customers tend to skew younger and more tech‑forward, ignoring voice search means missing the channels where your audience is increasingly present. Voice searches often include phrases like “dispensary near me” or “best THC‑free gummies for sleep” (queries with strong purchase intent).

Voice and text search behave differently

Optimizing for traditional search alone won’t cut it. Voice queries differ in several key ways:

  • Longer, conversational queries: People speak naturally to voice assistants. They ask questions like “What’s the best CBD oil for beginners?” rather than typing “CBD oil beginner.” Voice queries often contain five or more words.
  • Intent for immediate answers: Voice users typically want a quick answer, not a list of links. Assistants usually read only one result or “featured snippet.” If your content isn’t ranking in the top spot, it may never be heard.
  • Conversational tone: Voice searches use everyday language, so stiff or overly technical copy may fail to match user intent.

These differences mean you must rethink keyword strategies, content structure and site optimization.

The Compliance Challenge

Before diving into optimization tactics, it’s important to understand compliance. Cannabis advertising is restricted at both federal and state levels. For example, New York forbids mascots or neon colors, in cannabis branding. On the federal side, the FDA has not approved cannabis for treating any disease, so making medical or therapeutic claims in marketing is prohibited.

When you optimize content for voice search, the compliance rules don’t change. If a voice assistant reads your blog post verbatim, that copy becomes an advertisement. Avoid language that could be construed as promising health benefits or targeting minors. Use neutral terms like “cannabis business” or “CBD product,” and always include appropriate age gating on landing pages.

How Voice Search Is Changing Cannabis Marketing

1. Local search becomes critical

A significant share of voice searches are local; 38 % of smartphone voice users use voice search to find businesses in their area. Moreover, 28 % of people call a business immediately after finding it via voice search. For dispensaries and delivery services, this behavior is invaluable. To capitalize on local voice search:

  • Claim and optimize your Google Business Profile: Ensure your business name, address and phone number are accurate and consistent across platforms. Add high‑quality photos (compliant images only) and include operating hours.
  • Incorporate “near me” phrases: Use natural, location‑based language in your content and metadata. For example, “licensed dispensary near Buffalo, NY.”
  • Encourage reviews: Positive, authentic reviews increase your chances of ranking in voice results. Always respond politely and avoid incentivizing reviews, which may violate platform policies.

2. Long‑tail keywords and FAQs dominate

Voice search thrives on long‑tail keywords and question‑based content. NisonCo recommends leveraging long‑tail keywords because they capture the conversational tone of voice searches. For cannabis brands, this could mean targeting phrases like:

  • “Where can I find organic CBD gummies in Buffalo?”
  • “What’s the difference between indica and sativa tinctures?”
  • “How to store cannabis edibles safely?”

Create blog posts, FAQ pages and how‑to guides that answer these questions directly. Structure content with headings that mirror the query and provide concise, factual answers. We have found that voice assistants often read the top featured snippet for a query, so aim to occupy that snippet by delivering clear, well‑formatted answers.

3. Conversational content and schema markup

Because voice assistants parse natural speech, your copy should sound like a helpful conversation. Write in the second person (“you”) and avoid jargon. At the same time, help search engines understand your content by implementing schema markup. Structured data, such as FAQ schema and LocalBusiness schema, tells Google and voice assistants exactly what your page contains and increases the chance of being selected as a voice answer.

Voice search and AI search are converging. As mg Magazine reports, Google’s AI Overviews often present answers directly on the results page, reducing click‑through rates to as low as 8 % when AI summaries are shown versus 15 % without them. Generative Engine Optimization (GEO) is becoming as important as traditional SEO. While not strictly voice search, this underscores the importance of producing in‑depth, authoritative content that AI models—and by extension voice assistants—trust enough to cite. Provide evidence of expertise, like license numbers and author bios, to improve credibility.

4. Mobile performance and accessibility matter more than ever

Voice searches are largely performed on mobile devices. If your site loads slowly or isn’t mobile‑friendly, visitors will bounce before they even hear your answer. Use responsive design, optimize images and compress files to ensure fast load times. The GWI study emphasizes that voice technology is a lifeline for consumers with visual or physical impairments, so accessible design isn’t just considerate—it’s good business. Add alt tags to images and ensure your site works with screen readers.

5. Data privacy and user trust

Voice search relies on personal assistants that collect user data. Cannabis shoppers are already wary of privacy due to the plant’s legal status. Be transparent about your data practices: include privacy policies, comply with all relevant laws (e.g., the California Consumer Privacy Act for California users) and avoid retargeting minors. The mg Magazine article warns that search filters can suppress cannabis content due to “your money or your life” safety rules, so building trust through transparent operations and accurate labeling can improve your chances of appearing in AI‑generated voice answers.

Actionable Tips to Optimize for Voice Search

  1. Map out customer questions. Brainstorm or survey your customers to find common questions about your products, services and industry. Create content specifically addressing these queries.
  2. Use natural, question‑based headers. Structure each piece with H2/H3 headings that mirror how someone might ask the question aloud.
  3. Aim for concise answers. Provide a clear answer in the first paragraph of your section or post. Summarize in 30–50 words to increase your chances of being selected as a featured snippet.
  4. Implement structured data. Use FAQPage and HowTo schema for question/answer pages. Add LocalBusiness schema to location pages and include your license number (if applicable) to boost trust.
  5. Optimize for local. Include your city and neighborhood in copy and metadata. Keep your business information consistent across directories (NAP consistency).
  6. Focus on long‑tail keywords. Research high‑intent phrases and incorporate them naturally. Tools like Google’s Keyword Planner and AnswerThePublic can help.
  7. Ensure mobile and accessibility compliance. Use responsive design, compress images, and include alt text. Consider ARIA labels for better compatibility with voice‑controlled devices.
  8. Stay compliant. Avoid health or therapeutic claims. Don’t use imagery that appeals to minors or depicts consumption. Age‑gate your site and content.
  9. Measure and iterate. Track which pages are driving phone calls and conversions from voice search. Tools like CallRail or Google’s Performance Max can help you attribute voice search leads.

What’s Next for Cannabis Marketers?

Voice search is evolving quickly. Chatbots like ChatGPT now support voice prompts, merging voice search with conversational AI. mg Magazine warns that AI‑generated search answers could lead to 25 % less website traffic by 2026, making it even more critical to own the few available voice slots. To stay ahead:

  • Invest in authoritative content. Publish long‑form guides, original research and transparent supply‑chain documentation. AI and voice assistants reward depth and credibility.
  • Build your brand signal. Encourage branded search by promoting your company name across channels. Voice assistants are more likely to surface known, trusted brands.s
  • Monitor voice performance. Use analytics tools to see which queries trigger your content and adjust accordingly.
  • Collaborate with a specialized partner. Optimizing for voice search requires expertise in SEO, compliance and content strategy. Working with a cannabis‑specific marketing agency can streamline the process.

Conclusion and Next Steps

Voice search is no longer optional—it’s an essential part of modern cannabis marketing. With adoption climbing and AI‑powered assistants controlling which answers users hear, brands must adapt or risk obscurity. By understanding how voice queries differ, implementing structured data, focusing on conversational content and maintaining strict compliance, your cannabis business can lead the pack in this new search frontier.

Ready to make your brand voice‑search friendly? Book a discovery call to discuss a custom voice search strategy, or explore our Brand Foundation Worksheet and Competitive Analysis Template to lay the groundwork for better visibility. Voice search is reshaping the way people find cannabis businesses—don’t let your brand be silenced.
